messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] learning something new I did NOT want to learn at all, e...
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 4/14/2003 9:09:39 AM Central Daylight Time, ... Reminded me.  Get some Rescue Remedy.  I m not much into homeopathy or herbs, but I ve seen
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 4/14/2003 9:09:39 AM Central Daylight Time,
ddzimlew@... writes:

> When Dylan fell and gashed his forehead on my mil's coffee table she
> screamed and ran outside! If we hadn't been there what would have
> happened? I never left him with her, ever, and still wouldn't.
> That kind of panic reaction is just freaky.
>

Reminded me. Get some Rescue Remedy. I'm not much into homeopathy or herbs,
but I've seen that stuff work at calming an injured child down over and over
again, and I'm a believer. We were at the zoo Friday and one of the little
kids in our co-op fell off the bleachers and cut his head open. This is a
kid who screams in terror or rage or whatever at the slightest blip. His
mother didn't know what to do except hold him, and I had her apply pressure
to the wound, and then someone whipped out the Rescue Remedy. He was
screaming and crying and bleeding. I sprayed it on his head and grabbed one
of his wrists and gave him another squirt. He didn't know what it was. But
he literally stopped crying within 5 seconds!

I had been skeptical until that point. All the people I'd seen it used on
were capable of "believing" in it. This kid didn't even know what it was,
and he's known as a screamer who won't stop until he's good and done.

Sandra, maybe you can keep some around for YOURSELF, in case you have to do
that queasy stuff again.

Tuck


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] learning something new I did NOT want to learn at all, e...
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 4/14/03 11:43:25 AM Pacific Daylight Time, ... Dawn and everyone, I had to laugh at this because I was thinking the exact same thing and
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 4/14/03 11:43:25 AM Pacific Daylight Time,
astrologerdawn@... writes:

>
> Am I the only one of the list that love to have the opportunity to minister
> that kind of medical assistance!!!!! (LOL) I was fascinated by what you
> were able to do. I'm not afraid of blood, guts and the like and have
> actually assisted at a couple of accidents in my life. I sometimes think I
> missed my calling of being a medical doctor as I'm the kind of person that
> loves to watch operations on the tv.
>
>

Dawn and everyone,

I had to laugh at this because I was thinking the exact same thing and
wondered if I was some horrific person because everyone here was so grossed
out. I love that stuff. I'm always watching trauma in the ER and paramedics
and CSI is our family favorite. When I was six I announced that I wanted to
become a coroner! I always stayed up late to watch Quincy, M.E. Oddly, I
never did even though I still love it. I have some serious medical problems
myself so I have to do several different types of daily injections. My hubby
can't even watch me fill the syringe without feeling sick. But then again he
fears ever crossing me cuz poking him with on of those needles would be
enough to give him a heart attack.LOL I think he'd just as soon drive himself
to the hospital if he did what Keith did, because he knows I'd be thrilled to
get to operate. LOL

Have a great day everyone.
Rhonda


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.messageBody:
on 4/14/03 8:46 AM, Tuckervill@... at Tuckervill@... wrote:

> He did see worms that day, and when I told everyone about it, he still
> was able to eat some at snacktime. I think it worked a little to make him
> less sensitive about it.


You and Will are on "Fear Factor"? You didn't tell us!

;-) Nancy

messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] learning something new I did NOT want to learn at all, e...
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 4/14/2003 12:12:44 AM Central Daylight Time, ... Nah.  I wouldn t have cut it out myself, either, unless there was absolutely no other
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 4/14/2003 12:12:44 AM Central Daylight Time,
SandraDodd@... writes:

> Keith never even winced. He is so strong and so brave and I'm such a total
> crybaby wimp.
>

Nah. I wouldn't have cut it out myself, either, unless there was absolutely
no other choice. I don't get grossed out like that anymore, but I used to.
It was about worms. Couldn't eat, kept thinking about them and getting sick.


Now Will has the same kind of thing going on. Can't eat for DAYS if he's
seen worms. But you know, we had our little learning co-op a couple of weeks
ago and it was all about WORMS. He did fine with the ideas of worm castings,
etc., but when it was time to put his worm in the bottle to take home to
watch it make tunnels, he couldn't do it. Michelle did it for him, and he
looked at the tunnels later, but only after I made sure the worm wasn't in
them. He did see worms that day, and when I told everyone about it, he still
was able to eat some at snacktime. I think it worked a little to make him
less sensitive about it.

Maybe if you went ahead and thought about it some more and got used to the
idea? Take deep breaths and run it through your head like a movie? Kind of
like when someone has a phobia about escalators they take them to ride one in
the mall?

Tuck
